title: About Me
text: Did you ask who I am? Well, you’re about to find out.

title: You’ve encountered a mysterious link and you decided to see what’s in it…
text:
Typewriter Effect





Congratulations! You have been granted exclusive access to my website where numbers dance, charts come to life, and stories unfold with every click (they don’t but imagination exists for a reason). Behold, as you step into this digital sanctuary, you’ll find yourself surrounded by a tapestry of vibrant visualizations, each telling a tale waiting to be unraveled. From the peaks of histograms to the depths of scatter plots, every plot and point holds a secret, waiting for your keen eyes to uncover. So, gather ’round, and let the data speak to you in its mesmerizing language. Let curiosity be your compass, exploration your guide, and imagination your fuel as you dive deep into the heart of this captivating data story. It’s all up to you to explore! (Just please don’t skip my self intro). Go to your desired page by navigating the menu tab on the very top!

title: Study Performance Analysis
text: Academic performance is a multifaceted construct influenced by various factors that interact in complex ways. As a student myself, understanding the determinants of academic success is crucial for me to maintain my grades. Additionally, this helps to answer my curiosity on whether food is really key to excelling in studies.

title: Study Performance Analysis
text:
Aim
My analysis of study performance aims to delve into the diverse factors that impact study performance, shedding light on both individual and situational variables that contribute to academic outcomes.

title: Study Performance Analysis
text:
About Data Set
The data set that I am using for my analysis is from Kaggle by BHAVIK JIKADARA titled: “Student Study Performance”. The data-set contains marks secured by students in different subjects namely, Mathematics, Writing, and Reading, the students’ parents educational background, their test preparation course completion status, etc. The following is a glimpse of the data set:

title: About Me
text:
Self Introduction
Greetings! I’m Jacqueline Bernice Howard, a student at NUS majoring in Communications and New Media (I love CNM!). Despite my name sounding angmoh, I am not. As a matter of fact, I am a proud Indonesian who was born and raised in that country. Here’s a proof that I am not angmoh:





As I approach my 20th birthday later this year, I find myself reminiscing about my experiences over the last two decades. Having been a student nearly my entire life, I often wonder if my academic performance is affected by my gender or my parents’ education. In addition, many people have told me that if I prepared for tests, I would definitely ace them. However, I had experienced the opposite in the past where I thought I had prepared myself well but I ended up getting average grades. Hence, I decided to test whether a student’s grade is truly affected by test preparation, whether a student’s grade is affected by gender and parents’ educational background, and whether having lunch before tests matters.

title: My Data Story
text: Academic performance is a multifaceted construct influenced by various factors that interact in complex ways. As a student myself, understanding the determinants of academic success is crucial for me to maintain my grades. Additionally, this helps to answer my curiosity on whether preparation is the main key to excelling tests.

Gender and Average Score: Is there any difference between female and male?


Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.3.2






The median score appears to be higher for females than for males. However, the spread of scores appears to be larger for males than for females. One of the reasons for this might be that there are other factors besides gender that influence the test score, and these factors might have a larger effect on males than females.



    Two Sample t-test

data:  study$average_score by study$gender
t = 4.19, df = 998, p-value = 3.036e-05
alternative hypothesis: true difference in means between group female and group male is not equal to 0
95 percent confidence interval:
 1.993744 5.506248
sample estimates:
mean in group female   mean in group male 
             69.5695              65.8195 



But, how about within each subject (Math, Writing, Reading)?












Interestingly, when both genders are plotted against all three subjects, males appear to score higher in all subjects. There could be a number of reasons for this. For example, males might be more interested in certain subjects than females, or they might have had better teachers in those subjects.

title: Data Insights
text:
The variables in the “study_performance” data-set are as the following:

“Gender” to indicate sex of students (female or male)
“Race_Ethnicity” to indicate which racial group the students belong to
“Parental_Level_Of_Education” to indicate students’ parents final education (bachelor’s degree, some college, master’s degree, associate’s degree, high school)
“Lunch” to indicate whether students had their lunch before test (standard or free/reduced)
“Test_Preparation_Course” to indicate whether students had completed their test preparation or not
“Math_Score” to indicate students’ score in Maths
“Reading_Score” to indicate students’ score in Reading
“Writing_Score” to indicate students’ score in Writing
“Average_Score” to indicate students’ average score from all tests combined

title: Data Insights
text:
Comparing Score by Gender
By comparing scores, we can identify any gaps in academic performance between genders. This analysis can reveal whether one gender consistently outperforms the other in certain subjects or overall academic achievement.






Comparing Score by Gender, on average
As seen on the plot below, the median score appears to be higher for females than for males. However, the spread of scores appears to be larger for males than for females.







Comparing Score by Gender, in each subjects (Math, Writing, Reading)
However, upon looking how both genders scored in each subjects, we learned that the median score is higher for males than females in Math. On the other hand, females still tend to score higher than males in the two other subjects (Writing and Reading).

title: Data Insights
section: Parent’s Educational Background and Child’s Academic Performance: Are they related?
text:
Parent’s Educational Background and Child’s Academic Performance: Are they related?
Upon looking at scores comparison across both genders which shows that females tend to score higher than males, it comes to the question whether other factors such as students’ parents educational background influence the students or children’s academic performances.
According to the plot and histograms below, there is a positive correlation between parents’ educational background and students’ academic performances (average score). This means that students of parents with higher levels of education tend to score higher on average on academic tests.
However, it is important to note that correlation does not equal causation. There may be other factors that influence both parental education and child average scores. For example, children of wealthier families may be more likely to have parents with higher levels of education and also have access to better schools and resources.

title: Data Insights
text:
Pre-test Lunch: Does it matter?
According to Anderson et al. (2017), students with free or reduced-price lunches experienced more positive impact on test scores compared to those with standard lunches. Here, I will test whether students who ate free or reduced-price lunches indeed do better on tests than those who had standard lunches.





Based on the violin plot above, it appears that students with standard lunch has a higher median score than students who had free/reduced-price lunch. The violin for “standard lunch” is also narrower than the violin for “free/reduced lunch”, which means the scores in the “standard lunch” group are more clustered together. The tails of the violins are about the same length, which means the spread of the data is similar in both groups. In short, the violin plot suggests students who had standard lunch might score higher than those with free or reduced-price lunch.

title: Data Insights
section: Do well-prepared students always score higher than those who didn’t prepare?
text:
Do well-prepared students always score higher than those who didn’t prepare?





The group labeled “Completed” appears to have a higher average test score than the group labeled “None”. The average score for the “Completed” group is around 75, while the average score for the “None” group is closer to 50. Overall, the graph suggests that taking a test preparation course may be associated with higher test scores.

title: My Data Story
text: Academic performance is a multifaceted construct influenced by various factors that interact in complex ways. As a student myself, understanding the determinants of academic success is crucial for me to maintain my grades. Additionally, this helps to answer my curiosity on whether preparation is the main key to excelling tests.

title: My Data Story
text:
Aim
My analysis of study performance aims to delve into the diverse factors that impact study performance, shedding light on both individual and situational variables that contribute to academic outcomes.

title: My Data Story
text:
About Data Set
The data set that I am using for my analysis is from Kaggle by BHAVIK JIKADARA titled: “Student Study Performance”. The data-set contains marks secured by students in different subjects namely, Mathematics, Writing, and Reading, the students’ parents educational background, their test preparation course completion status, etc. The following is a glimpse of the data set:


Rows: 1,048,575
Columns: 8
$ Gender                      <chr> "Male", "Female", "Female", "Male", "Male"…
$ Race_Ethnicity              <chr> "Group E", "Group E", "Group E", "Group A"…
$ Parental_Level_Of_Education <chr> "associate's degree", "some college", "bac…
$ Lunch                       <chr> "Free/Reduced", "Standard", "Standard", "S…
$ Test_Preparation_Course     <chr> "Completed", "None", "None", "Completed", …
$ Math_Score                  <int> 100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 100, 99, 99,…
$ Reading_Score               <int> 100, 92, 100, 96, 97, 100, 100, 100, 93, 8…
$ Writing_Score               <int> 93, 97, 100, 86, 99, 100, 100, 100, 90, 81…

title: My Data Story
text:
Variables that will be used
In the visualization of the dataset, all variables above will be incorporated, excluding “Race_Ethnicity.” This exclusion is due to the dataset categorizing individuals into broader groups labeled as “Group A”, “Group B”, “Group C”, “Group D”, and “Group E” without specifying the specific races or ethnicities represented. This approach is chosen to ensure sensitivity and avoid potential misinterpretations associated with racial or ethnic classifications.

title: Discussion
text:
Gender Differences in Scores by Subject
My initial observation shows gender-based differences in overall scores as well as by individual subjects. It’s clear that while females generally score higher overall, males have higher median scores in Math. This finding could lead to further investigations into potential reasons for these differences, which might include societal expectations, teaching methods, or even inherent biases in the way subjects are taught or assessed. Additionally, the higher scores in Writing and Reading for females may reflect greater verbal skills, which has been supported by some educational research.



Parents’ Educational Background
The positive correlation between parents’ educational levels and student academic performance is a critical insight. This relationship suggests that parental education could be a proxy for a variety of factors, such as higher socio-economic status, more educational resources available at home, or a greater emphasis on the value of education. To explore this further, it might be useful to look at specific educational interventions or support systems that are in place for students whose parents have lower levels of education, to see if these can mitigate the observed differences.



Influence of Lunch Status on Academic Performance
My analysis of lunch status presents an intriguing contradiction to the claim by Anderson et al. (2017). While they found a positive impact of free or reduced-price lunches on test scores, my data shows that students with standard lunches actually score higher. This discrepancy could be due to several factors such as:
Economic Factors: Free or reduced-price lunch status is often a marker of lower economic status, which could correlate with less access to academic resources, such as books, private tutoring, or quiet study environments.
School Resources: Schools with higher proportions of students who qualify for free or reduced-price lunches may receive less funding or have fewer resources, affecting the quality of education provided.



Effect of Test Preparation Courses:
The data indicating that students who completed a test preparation course scored higher on average than those who did not strongly supports the idea that structured preparation and study can improve test outcomes. This effect might be due to better familiarity with test formats, enhanced confidence, and improved knowledge retention.



Further Investigation and Considerations
To delve deeper into these observations, it might be useful to conduct multivariate analyses that include several factors at once, such as parental education, lunch status, and perhaps other demographic variables like race or geographic location. This could help determine the relative impact of each factor while controlling for the others.
Additionally, it could be valuable to investigate qualitative factors such as student motivation, teacher quality, or school climate, which are harder to measure but can significantly influence academic performance.
In conclusion, while my data analysis provides important insights, it also opens up several avenues for further research. Understanding these patterns can help in designing targeted interventions that address the underlying causes of academic disparities.
